newsitem.title: ITALY: Alitalia says will not change rescue plan.
newsitem.headline: Alitalia says will not change rescue plan.

text.p: Alitalia said on Wednesday it would press ahead with a rescue plan aimed at bringing the debt-ridden Italian airline back to profit despite criticism of the project by the European Commission.

Alitalia managing director Domenico Cempella said in a statement that it was too late to change the plan and accused the commission of "a serious and prejudiced attitude" against the state-controlled airline.

Earlier on Wednesday, the European Commission said it had sent a letter to the Italian government suggesting certain changes to plans to inject fresh funds into struggling Alitalia. It gave no further details.

Italy requested EU permission last year for a capital injection of 3.3 trillion lire ($1.9 billion) into Alitalia and the government has already authorised state holding IRI to hand over some 1.5 trillion lire of the funds.

"We cannot accept at this point requests for further changes to a plan which we believe in and which is bringing the company back to the path of strong recovery," Cempella said in a speech to Alitalia directors which was released to the media.
It said the Commission was wrong if it saw the cash injection as state aid.

"We do not understand how the Commission can express perplexity on a recapitalisation plan that fully conforms to the needs of the Alitalia plan, which is, and must remain, a plan for the relaunch of the company," Cempella said.
Alitalia chalked up losses of around 1.3 trillion lire in 1996 -- its ninth straight year in the red.
Unions at the company on Wednesday asked for "an urgent meeting" with Prime Minister Romano Prodi in the wake of the European Commission's criticisms.
In a statement, the unions said they were: "deeply worried by the situation regarding the Alitalia plan and the European Commission".
Alitalia management was locked in bitter conflict with unions for more than a year over plans to slash hefty personnel costs and boost productivity.

A truce was finally called last June when labour leaders agreed to a rescue package which allowed for between 20-30 percent of the group's shares to be reserved for employees after the firm's recapitalisation and eventual privatisation. -- Rome newsroom +396 6782501
